Ramiro,

I would suggest using the second approach.  It will probably be faster
and require much less memory.  In fact, the second approach
is the one taken in the 1D flame applications and in the 0D reactor
network application 
that are already in Cantera.  
 
If you are working in python, I would think that for efficiency reasons

you will eventually want to rewrite code to avoid doing any explicit
looping in 
python over the cells, particularly if there is a Cantera call within. 
 Instead you 
will probably want to pass your arrays through a wrapper into C,C++ or
fortran
and access the Cantera functionality from there.   
 
Additionally, there are two general packages which provide the
differential operators 
which you might find useful in building a reacting flow code in
python:
finite volume:      http://www.ctcms.nist.gov/fipy/
finite difference:  http://pyfdm.sourceforge.net/
 
Also, you might find some of the earlier versions of Cantera (< v1.3)
useful, since these had
a larger proportion of python code in the 1D flame application.
 
Dave H.

>>> willmerstrog@... 3/15/2006 8:41 PM >>>

Hello,

I have just installed and given a quick look through most of
the available documentation. I think it is a good fit to my
problem, but I'd like the opinion of other more experienced
users before I dive fully in.

I'm thinking of using cantera as "chemistry engine" for a
CFD code I'm developing. I'm mostly interested, at this time, on
phase equilibrium, but I'm *very* interested on adding chemical
reactions later on.

I intend to write mostly in python, with numpy (numarray
to stay compatible with cantera) using finite differences.
The domains (and the number of cells) can be really big.

Would you think cantera is appropriate for this?
If this does not sound too absurd, I have another question.

I haven't really looked at cantera's code yet, but I'm already
thinking how to adapt it to a CFD code.

The fist and obvious way is to work with arrays of Cantera
phases, ie, to store in each (of the many many thousands) cell
a cantera phase, and use it's own internal variables on each cell
to keep track of molar fractions, etc. This would be _very_ neat,
but I'm afraid there could be too much overhead, since a lot of
the information would be replicated on all cells.

The other would be to store everything myself, and just invoke
cantera passing the full thermodynamical state to it. This looks kind
of gross, considering I'd be wasting a lot of the good thinking and
hard work Dr. Goodwin already applied to this problem! In the end I'd
end up replicating most of the phases and fluid classes (which I
already had started to do, before I decided to check the internet,
just in case someone had had the same problem before, and here I am).

Sorry for the long post, any comments or suggestions most welcome.

Best regards,

Ramiro.
